docs.title: Naturally Linux
docs.text: Naturally Linux is a command-line tool that converts natural-language requests into safe, reviewable Linux shell commands. It previews the generated command, explains what it does, and executes only after confirmation.

docs.title: Why it exists
docs.text: Shell commands can be terse and easy to misremember. Naturally Linux lets you describe tasks in plain English and translates them into commands you can review and run.

docs.title: Key features
docs.text:
• Natural-language → shell command generation
  • Command preview and explanation
  • Safety checks for potentially destructive operations
  • Confirmation before execution

docs.title: Quick start
docs.text:
pip install naturally-linux
export GROQ_API_KEY="your-key"

naturally-linux "list files larger than 10MB"

For a dry-run with explanation only:

naturally-linux "list files larger than 10MB" --dry-run

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The CLI is split into focused modules:

  • cli.py: Typer app and command wiring
  • generator.py: LLM inference and prompt handling
  • safety.py: safety checks for commands
  • executor.py: execution via subprocess
  • config.py: local config storage for API key

docs.title: Flow
docs.text:
1. User provides a prompt
  2. generate_command() calls Groq to produce a command
  3. unsafe_reasons() and heuristics evaluate risk
  4. Command is shown to the user
  5. If confirmed, run_command() executes it with a timeout

docs.title: Extension points
docs.text:
• Swap the LLM provider in generator.py
  • Add advanced safety policies in safety.py
  • Add stronger sandboxing in executor.py

docs.title: Does Naturally Linux run commands automatically?
docs.text: No. It always shows the generated command and asks for confirmation unless you pass --yes.

docs.title: Why do I need a Groq API key?
docs.text: The command generator uses Groq’s LLM API. Each user should provide their own API key.

docs.title: Can I use a different model provider?
docs.text: Yes. Replace the Groq client in generator.py with your provider of choice.

docs.title: Is this safe for production servers?
docs.text: Review every command. The current safety filter is basic and does not replace human judgment.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.13+
  • A Groq API key

docs.title: Install with UV (recommended)
docs.text:
Install UV (by Astral) and then install the CLI system-wide. See the official UV docs: UV by Astral

curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
uv tool install naturally-linux

docs.title: Install from PyPI (pip)
docs.text: pip install naturally-linux

docs.title: Set the API key
docs.text:
Recommended (stored locally in config):

naturally-linux config set-key YOUR_GROQ_API_KEY

Alternative (environment variable):

export GROQ_API_KEY="your-key"

The CLI uses this priority: environment variable first, then config file.

docs.title: Verify
docs.text: naturally-linux --help

docs.title: Safety
docs.text: Naturally Linux applies a basic safety filter before running commands. This reduces the chance of accidental destructive actions.

docs.title: Current behavior
docs.text:
The tool flags commands containing patterns like:

  • rm -rf
  • mkfs
  • dd if=
  • Fork bombs like :(){
  • shutdown or reboot

If a command is flagged, you will be warned with the reason and asked to confirm explicitly.

docs.title: Heuristic warnings
docs.text:
The CLI also warns about potentially expensive or system-wide operations, such as:

  • Root-level scans like find /
  • Recursive scans across /
  • Commands using sudo

When detected, the CLI will display a risk level and require explicit confirmation.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text: This is a simple substring-based check. It can miss risky commands or flag safe ones. Always review the proposed command.

docs.title: Planned improvements
docs.text:
• Regex-based rules
  • Allow/deny lists by environment
  • Context-aware risk analysis
  • Structured command parsing

docs.title: Generate and run a command
docs.text:
naturally-linux "find files modified today"

The CLI will:

  1. Generate a command from your prompt
  2. Perform a safety check
  3. Show the proposed command
  4. Ask for confirmation
  5. Execute and display output

docs.title: Dry run
docs.text:
Use --dry-run to preview the command and receive an explanation without running it:

naturally-linux "list directories" --dry-run

You can still choose to execute after reviewing the explanation.

docs.title: Auto-approve
docs.text:
Skip confirmation with --yes:

naturally-linux "list files" --yes

Use this carefully. It bypasses the confirmation prompt.

docs.title: Timeout
docs.text:
Set an execution timeout in seconds:

naturally-linux "scan logs" --timeout 10

docs.title: API key management
docs.text:
naturally-linux config set-key YOUR_GROQ_API_KEY
naturally-linux config show
naturally-linux config delete
